newsitem.title: USA: Two indicted in murder of Time Warner chief's son.
newsitem.headline: Two indicted in murder of Time Warner chief's son.

text.p: Two young New Yorkers were indicted on Thursday in the torture and killing of Jonathan Levin, the son of Time Warner Inc.'s top executive.
Corey Arthur, a 19-year-old paroled crack dealer and a former student of Levin's at a city high school, was indicted on charges of first- and second-degree murder and robbery.
His alleged accomplice, Montoun Hart, 25, was indicted on charges of second-degree murder and robbery.

Levin, 31, was the son of Gerald Levin, chief executive and chairman of the media conglomerate Time Warner. He was found on June 2 in his one-bedroom Manhattan apartment, stabbed and shot once in the head. He had been bound and gagged, and there was no sign of forced entry.

Levin was a popular teacher at New York's Taft High School who befriended struggling students. Lawyers for Arthur, however, said they were investigating an unspecified "substantial" relationship between Levin and their client.

"There was a relationship between Mr. Levin and Corey Arthur and that relationship is going to play a part in this case," Tony Ricco, Arthur's lead attorney, told reporters outside Manhattan's Supreme Court building.
Hart, who has a number of convictions for such crimes as petty larceny, faces up to life in prison if convicted. Arthur could face the death penalty or life without parole.
The two were expected to enter pleas when they are formally arraigned. Hart's arraignment is scheduled for June 26 and Arthur's for July 7.
Police allege Levin was murdered for his automatic bank teller card.
